ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture, no recordings.
We had a virtual seminar and frequently utilized breakout rooms to engage with other classmates.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic Korean writing, speaking, reading language skills.

I developed the ability to read Hangul and to form basic sentences using the low-formal and high-formal conjugations for the present, past, and future tenses. I also learned how to tell time and talk about daily activities.

I learned how to read, write, listen, and speak basic Korean. I learned how to construct common sentence forms in past, present, and future tense. Topics of discussion included activities, school, travel, directions, family, Korea, etc.
I learned to speak some baby Korean and learned more about the culture.
From this class, I learned how to read the Korean alphabet and basic grammatical structuring.
I learned the basics of Korean.
i improved my basic Korean skills and built upon my vocabulary

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was well-organized for learning and very enjoyable. I really don't think this class has any weaknesses!
The course does what it needs to for a beginner's language course. It moves at a rapid pace and ensures that students get sufficient exposure to the concepts during and after/outside of class.

Strengths: Prof. Lim Hyunsung is truly amazing! He made the class so much fun and was super nice to all of us. The powerpoint slides, study guides, and workbook assignments were all very helpful in learning and preparing for the tests. The tests were fair and graded generously. The homework is graded on completion, so even though it could be tricky at times it was okay to get things wrong which made it a lot less stressful. I really enjoyed the cultural presentation and presentation about an event in 2020. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the listening and occasionally the workbook assignments could be frustrating when they incorporated too many new words or grammar constructions that we didn't cover in class.
Strengths: very thorough and organized, perfect balance between speaking and writing assignments, engaging lessons, a lot of time for practice

This course was well structured, and the topics that we learned built upon each other. At the beginning, there were a lot of quizzes, but towards the latter half there was not as many. This was the only thing that seemed imbalanced about the class, otherwise the content was greatly presented and easy to understand.
Amazing format and manageable workload! Prof. Lim is wonderful!
the strengths were that it was very engaging and there were no weaknesses.

Strengths: amazing professor, fun and easy to understand class sessions, reasonable assignments
Weakness: maybe too much time in breakout rooms

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of breakout rooms was very effective because it allowed for practice in smaller groups.

The use of breakout rooms along with the instructor still being able to talk to us 1 on 1 was very helpful. The instructor made sure to make himself available to all of us as needed, even in a virtual format.
Having class live each day on zoom was totally fine. Professor Lim Hyunsung made effective use of breakout rooms and was quick to electronically grade our homework.

The breakout rooms were very helpful in that I was able to practice speaking and working on a closer level with my classmates. It definitely is not the same as learning Korean in person but it worked.

I liked that we were able to practice our speaking and conversations in breakout rooms, but it seemed as though the professor let us stay in breakout rooms for a little longer than needed most times. I also liked the audio portfolios as it provided direct feedback on our pronunciation and was a way to check how we were doing each chapter.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely! I have learned so much and this class has motivated me to take more Korean classes. The class environment is also very positive and engaging.

Definitely! If someone is interested in beginning to learn Korean, this course is perfect. It simply is a matter of being willing to put in the time to actually be engaged in class and to ensure that you fully understand the concepts after each lesson.

Yes! Korean 1 is a really fun class and not too hard even for non-heritage speakers. Definitely take it if you have some interest in Korea. As long as you do all the homework and study a little bit you can easily succeed in the class.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in learning to speak Korean. My language abilities have greatly improved in only 1 semester. I am able to form sentences, hold basic conversations, and read.
I would recommend this course for anyone looking to learn a fun and easy language! Korean is really easy to pick up and is great for anyone looking for a low stress language credit.
Yes! If youre looking to learn a new language or just have space in your schedule for a fun class, take Korean!
yes, it was very easy to follow and the instructor is great.
Yes! Its a fun class and refreshing break from other less fun classes
